title: Top 5 Tips for Students Living Alone Abroad
text:
Flying Abroad!
Studying abroad is an unforgettable experience but living alone in a new country can definitely be challenging at first. During my year in Marseille, France, I learned a lot about adapting to a new environment, building independence, and overcoming unexpected challenges. Here are my top 5 tips for students preparing to live alone abroad:

title: Top 5 Tips for Students Living Alone Abroad
section: 1. Sort Out Essentials Early ‚Äî Especially Accommodation and Admin
text:
1. Sort Out Essentials Early ‚Äî Especially Accommodation and Admin
Before arriving, start searching for accommodation as early as possible. In my case, starting late made it harder to find a good place and it added a lot of unnecessary stress. If you can, aim to secure housing close to your university to make commuting easier, especially if you have early classes. Also, make setting up your local SIM card, bank account, transport card, and housing insurance a top priority during your first week it will save you so much hassle later. üí° Tip: Some services require a local phone number ‚Äî get that sorted quickly!

title: Top 5 Tips for Students Living Alone Abroad
section: 2. Get Comfortable with Budgeting, Bills and Cooking!
text:
2. Get Comfortable with Budgeting, Bills and Cooking!
Living alone means taking charge of your finances and your meals. Aside from rent, factor in utility bills like electricity, Wi-Fi, and heating if they aren‚Äôt included. Platforms like Papernest helped me set up my electricity and Wi-Fi accounts when I moved to Marseille services like this can make a big difference in getting settled smoothly. Cooking for yourself is another essential part of living abroad. While it can be tempting to rely on takeaways at first, learning to cook simple meals is not only healthier but also saves a lot of money. Meal prepping on Sundays helped me stay organised for the week and soon it became something I genuinely enjoyed. üí° Tip: Start with a few easy recipes you like having a go-to pasta dish, curry, or stir-fry makes weekday life much easier.

title: Top 5 Tips for Students Living Alone Abroad
section: 3. Build a Routine It Grounds You
text:
3. Build a Routine It Grounds You
Having a routine when you‚Äôre living abroad creates a sense of normality and stability. Whether it‚Äôs a weekly trip to the bakery (trust me, in France this became part of my life!) or planning Sunday grocery runs early before shops close, small habits help you feel more grounded. I also recommend creating a study schedule that fits around your new timetable especially if classes start earlier than you‚Äôre used to. At Kedge Business School, classes could begin at 8:30am, so adjusting my sleep routine became a must! üí° Tip: Sundays in many European cities are very quiet plan ahead for shopping and activities.

title: Top 5 Tips for Students Living Alone Abroad
section: 4. Stay Open to New Experiences, But Prioritise Safety
text:
4. Stay Open to New Experiences, But Prioritise Safety
Exploring a new city is one of the best parts of studying abroad but staying safe is important too, especially if you‚Äôre living alone. Learn which areas are best avoided after dark and stay informed through local news or apps. In Marseille, I learned quickly which arrondissements were safer for students, especially when travelling alone. Building a local support network like meeting other exchange students made a huge difference for me. University groups, associations, and orientation events are great ways to meet people and create friendships. üí° Tip: Share your location with a trusted friend when exploring somewhere new for the first time.

title: Top 5 Tips for Students Living Alone Abroad
text:
5. Embrace Growth Through the Challenges
Living alone abroad isn‚Äôt always glamorous there will be hard days. But every moment, from handling admin in a foreign language to fixing small problems in your flat, builds resilience and independence. Studying abroad taught me how to manage stress, adapt to new routines, and develop the confidence to handle unexpected problems on my own. It also gave me space to rediscover hobbies like sketching, to explore new cities, and to learn practical life skills like cooking something I didn‚Äôt expect to enjoy as much as I did. üí° Tip: Keep a small journal during your time abroad reflecting on challenges and wins helps you appreciate how much you‚Äôre growing.
Living alone abroad is an experience that will test you but it will also shape you in the best possible ways. Every challenge becomes a stepping stone to becoming stronger, more confident, and more adaptable for life after university.

section: Specialising in Data Analytics: Finding My Path
text:
Specialising in Data Analytics: Finding My Path



Impax Asset Management


Choosing to specialise in data analytics wasn‚Äôt something I initially planned from the very beginning of university. It was through real-world experience particularly my internship at Impax Asset Management, that I realised how much I enjoyed working with data. Getting to apply technical skills, draw insights, and contribute to solving real business problems gave me a sense of purpose that made the decision to specialise feel natural. The experience showed me that data is not just about numbers it‚Äôs about storytelling, decision-making, and finding ways to make systems and strategies better. It gave me clarity and excitement about the kind of work I want to continue doing after university.
## Final Year: A Journey of Highs, Lows, and Growth Final year was by no means easy. Unforeseen circumstances made parts of the year more difficult than I ever could have anticipated ‚Äî moments where balancing coursework, deadlines, and personal life felt overwhelming. But despite the tough days, I kept pushing forward, and every challenge became part of a bigger story of resilience. Final year demanded more discipline, adaptability, and self-belief than any previous year. While the pressure was real, it also showed me just how far I‚Äôve come and that I‚Äôm capable of more than I sometimes give myself credit for.

title: Finishing Final Year: Reflections, Challenges, and New Beginnings
text:
How University Changed Me
Looking back on my entire university journey, one of the things I‚Äôm most grateful for is how much it helped me come out of my shell. When I first started, I was much quieter and more hesitant to step outside of my comfort zone. But through group projects, international experiences, internships, and all the ups and downs in between, I‚Äôve grown into someone who‚Äôs more confident, open, and excited about embracing new opportunities. University wasn‚Äôt just about academic learning it was about learning who I am, what matters to me, and how I want to move forward into the next chapter.

title: Finishing Final Year: Reflections, Challenges, and New Beginnings
text:
Looking Ahead: Graduation and Beyond
Now, as I look ahead to graduation and life after university, I feel a mixture of excitement, nerves, and optimism. While the future still holds plenty of unknowns, I‚Äôm proud of how far I‚Äôve come and excited for what‚Äôs next whether that‚Äôs starting a new role, continuing to grow my skills, or simply learning more about myself along the way. University was a chapter full of growth, change, and discovery, and I‚Äôm grateful for every part of it. Here‚Äôs to celebrating the end of one journey and the start of something completely new.

title: Machine Learning Reflection
text: With the rapid spread of misinformation during the COVID-19 pandemic, automated systems for detecting fake news have become increasingly important. This project developed and evaluated a machine learning approach to classify COVID-19 news headlines as either fake (class 0) or real (class 1).

title: Machine Learning Reflection
text:
The Challenge
The COVID-19 pandemic was accompanied by what health officials called an ‚Äúinfodemic‚Äù ‚Äì a flood of both accurate and inaccurate information that made it difficult for people to find reliable guidance. Fake news provides comfort during uncertainty but can lead to dangerous behaviours like mask refusal and vaccine hesitancy.
While human fact-checking exists through websites like PolitiFact and Snopes, these methods:

Require human expertise to identify fake articles
Cannot scale to the volume of content being produced
Are not generalisable across different topics

title: Machine Learning Reflection
text:
Dataset & Methodology
The dataset consisted of 10,202 news headlines labelled as real (1) or fake (0). Initial exploration revealed a significant class imbalance of 20.5:1, with fake news being the majority class. To address this, I implemented:

Text preprocessing and normalisation techniques
TF-IDF vectorisation for feature extraction
Train/validation/test splits (60%/20%/20%)
Two oversampling techniques (Random Oversampling and SMOTE)
Three classification algorithms (Decision Tree, Random Forest, Logistic Regression)
Hyperparameter tuning with GridSearchCV

title: Machine Learning Reflection
text:
Conclusion

Key Findings Random Forest with SMOTE achieved the highest performance (F1 score: 0.6803, accuracy: 0.9770).
Text length analysis revealed real news headlines had more consistent lengths than fake ones.
Feature importance analysis showed that terms like ‚Äúgoogle,‚Äù ‚Äúcovid,‚Äù and ‚Äúcoronavirus‚Äù were strong predictors.
Despite oversampling, the model still showed bias toward the majority class.
The model had high precision (0.9070) but lower recall (0.4105) for real news.

title: Machine Learning Reflection
text:
Technologies Used

Python (scikit-learn, pandas, numpy, matplotlib)
Natural Language Processing techniques
TF-IDF vectorisation
Oversampling techniques (SMOTE)
Machine learning algorithms (Decision Tree, Random Forest, Logistic Regression)
Cross-validation and hyperparameter tuning

title: Bord Bia Strategic Consulting
text:
Methodology
We applied several strategic frameworks to analyse Bord Bia‚Äôs position and develop recommendations:

PESTLE Analysis for macro-environmental factors
Porter‚Äôs Five Forces for industry competition
SWOT Analysis for organisational capabilities
Financial modelling for market expansion projections

title: Bord Bia Strategic Consulting
text:
Key Findings

Bord Bia is well-positioned to leverage its sustainability credentials in the premium Halal food sector in the UAE
29% of UAE consumers are willing to pay premium prices for quality-assured beef
Break-even analysis showed decreasing volume requirements (from 6.7 to 4.2 tonnes) over a 5-year period
Blockchain-enabled traceability can enhance consumer trust in Halal certification
Alternative protein development aligns with Bord Bia‚Äôs sustainability leadership

title: Bord Bia Strategic Consulting
text:
Strategic Recommendations
Our recommendations followed a four-phase implementation approach: 1. Establishment: Partnerships with UAE certification bodies (ESMA, HIA) 2. Market Penetration: Premium pricing strategy focusing on sustainability and quality 3. Marketing: Digital-first approach targeting HORECA sector 4. Scaling: Expansion to Southeast Asian markets following UAE success

title: Bord Bia Strategic Consulting
text:
Conclusion
The strategic interventions identified will strengthen Bord Bia‚Äôs global position, drive long-term growth, and reinforce Ireland‚Äôs reputation as a leader in sustainable food production.

title: AI Ethics in Recruitment
text: This group project examines AI bias in recruitment, focusing on ethical challenges and solutions. It analyses Amazon‚Äôs biased hiring tool, explores sustainability frameworks, and proposes institutional reforms to ensure fairness.

title: AI Ethics in Recruitment
text:
Key Issues

AI recruitment tools often replicate societal biases, disadvantaging marginalised groups.
Flawed training data and lack of diversity in development teams exacerbate discrimination.
Cases like Amazon‚Äôs gender-biased algorithm highlight systemic risks.

title: AI Ethics in Recruitment
text:
Sustainability Frameworks
Triple Bottom Line: Balances profit with social/ethical factors (e.g., Google‚Äôs gendered job ads prioritising efficiency over equity).
Stakeholder Theory: Emphasises fairness alongside shareholder interests.
SDGs Alignment: AI recruitment must support gender equality (SDG 5) and reduced inequalities (SDG 10).

title: AI Ethics in Recruitment
text:
Case Study: Amazon‚Äôs Biased AI
Issue: Tool trained on male-dominated data penalised female candidates (e.g., r√©sum√©s with ‚Äúwomen‚Äôs‚Äù).
Root Cause: Biased historical data and homogenous development team.
Outcome: Project scrapped (2018), sparking global debate on ethical AI.

title: AI Ethics in Recruitment
text:
Proposed Solutions
Regulatory Measures:

Mandate annual AI bias audits (e.g., EU AI Act, New York‚Äôs laws).
Require transparency in algorithmic decision-making.

Organisational Actions:

Diversify training data and development teams.
Integrate human oversight with AI tools.

Institutional Collaboration:

Joint research initiatives to address bias.

title: AI Ethics in Recruitment
text:
Conclusion
While implementing audits and reforms is costly, these steps are critical for ethical AI recruitment. Aligning with SDGs ensures long-term equity and trust in AI systems.

title: Why I Chose to Specialise in Data Analytics
text:
Data Analytics!
When I first started university, I wasn‚Äôt entirely sure what career path I wanted to take. Studying International Business gave me a wide view of many different areas but it wasn‚Äôt until I gained real-world experience that my path became clear.

title: Why I Chose to Specialise in Data Analytics
text:
Discovering My Interest Through Experience
During my summer internship as a Risk and Fund Services Intern, I began working closely with data every day. I saw firsthand how businesses rely on data to drive decisions, improve efficiency, and meet regulatory standards. Transforming raw information into meaningful insights using tools like Excel, Power BI, and SQL became one of the parts of my job that I genuinely enjoyed. It was during this experience that I realised how powerful well-analysed data can be. It isn‚Äôt just about numbers it‚Äôs about storytelling, supporting strategic thinking, and making complex information understandable for wider teams. Seeing the direct impact of clear data insights made me excited to explore this area further and so choosing to specialise in Data Analytics felt like a natural step.

title: Why I Chose to Specialise in Data Analytics
section: What I Love About Data Analytics
text:
What I Love About Data Analytics
There are a few key reasons why Data Analytics feels like the right fit for me:
- Problem-Solving: I enjoy breaking down complex problems and uncovering insights that might not be immediately obvious.
- Visual Communication: Creating dashboards and visualisations helps turn raw data into something accessible, understandable, and valuable.
- Technical Skills Development: I find it rewarding to continue learning and building technical skills through platforms like Power BI, SQL databases, and Python fundamentals.
- Real-World Application: Data is used across every industry. I love that my skills will allow me to work in diverse sectors, solving a wide range of real-world challenges.

title: Why I Chose to Specialise in Data Analytics
text:
Looking Ahead
As I move into the next stage of my professional journey, I‚Äôm excited to continue growing my skills in data analytics. I hope to contribute to organisations by helping them unlock the power of their data ‚Äî improving decision-making, driving innovation, and creating meaningful impact.
Choosing this path wasn‚Äôt something I planned at the start of university, but sometimes the best decisions are the ones shaped by real experiences. I‚Äôm looking forward to seeing where this journey leads.

title: Reflecting on My Year Abroad and Entering Final Year
text: I had the incredible opportunity to study abroad at Kedge Business School in Marseille, France, as part of my International Business degree at DCU. Looking back, it‚Äôs hard to sum up how much I‚Äôve grown personally, academically, and professionally from this experience ‚Äî but I wanted to share a few reflections as I enter my final year of university.

title: Reflecting on My Year Abroad and Entering Final Year
section: A New Adventure: Living and Studying in France
text:
A New Adventure: Living and Studying in France
Moving to a new country came with challenges I hadn‚Äôt anticipated ‚Äî from finding accommodation to adapting to a completely different education system. At Kedge Business School, I adjusted to three-hour-long classes, stricter attendance policies, and a strong emphasis on group work and presentations. Although it was difficult at first, these differences helped me develop stronger communication, time management, and teamwork skills. Living in Marseille meant immersing myself in a new culture. I loved exploring the city‚Äôs coastal beauty, local traditions, and vibrant student life. Although simple things ‚Äî like finding an open shop on Sundays or navigating language barriers ‚Äî sometimes tested my patience, they also taught me resilience and adaptability.

title: Reflecting on My Year Abroad and Entering Final Year
text:
Exploring New Places
One of the biggest highlights of my year abroad was the opportunity to travel.



The Calanque, Marseille


Being based in the south of France made it easy to visit nearby towns, coastal villages, and even other countries. I had the chance to explore beautiful places like Morocco and Barcelona ‚Äî experiences that truly broadened my perspective and allowed me to pursue one of my favourite hobbies: travelling.
 During my trip to Morocco, I was able to explore a culture completely different from my own. From the vibrant markets to the rich traditions and hospitality, it was an unforgettable experience that opened my eyes to new ways of life and deepened my appreciation for cultural diversity.



Sagrada Fam√≠lia


 In Barcelona, I also had the opportunity to tap into my love for art. From visiting famous landmarks like the Sagrada Fam√≠lia to seeing incredible pieces and exploring the city‚Äôs vibrant street art scene, it was inspiring to experience so much creativity in one place. These moments reminded me of how much I enjoy art and how travel can reconnect us with our passions.

title: Reflecting on My Year Abroad and Entering Final Year
text:
Growth Beyond the Classroom
My year abroad wasn‚Äôt just about academics ‚Äî it was about personal growth too.

I became more confident stepping outside of my comfort zone.
I strengthened my independence, managing life in a completely new environment.
I broadened my cultural awareness by meeting people from all over the world.

Small everyday experiences, like catching the early metro to my 8:30 am classes or trying new activities around Marseille, added up to a big transformation.
## Looking Ahead: Final Year and Beyond
As I now enter my final year at DCU, I feel a real sense of excitement and motivation. My exchange experience gave me fresh perspective, a stronger work ethic, and a clearer idea of how much I‚Äôm capable of. I look forward to building on everything I‚Äôve learned, making the most of my last year in university, and preparing for all the new opportunities to come after graduation.
